Media: Broadway News
Review: Some of its material may be straight from the stock shelves, but 'Bandstand' has more than a few fresh notes up its sleeve<U+2014>mostly blue ones...Blankenbuehler infuses the proceedings with a surging dynamism that virtually never lets up...Cott rips into the role of Donny with a vitality that scrubs away any of the role<U+2019>s surface familiarity...Osnes, too, deserves some major love for revitalizing what might be a plain-Jane ing<U+00E9>nue role...It<U+2019>s a populist crowd-pleaser.

Media: BroadwayWorld
Review: Exhilarating, adventurous and immensely moving...As toe-tapping entertaining as it is poignant...The writing and acting is perfectly on pitch...Director/choreographer Andy Blankenbuehler's slam-bang production, continually on the move, ingeniously uses his ensemble to not only express the new freedoms post-war Americans felt with the latest dance crazes, but also to symbolize the internal struggle of its heroic main characters.

Media: Time Out New York
Review: <U+201C>The resonant original musical <U+2018>Bandstand' dances a delicate line between nostalgia and disillusion<U+2026>The terrific group dance numbers burst with snazzy individuality. But 'Bandstand's' heart is in its shadows...As the stakes rise, the score moves from pleasurable pastiche to a climax whose impassioned call for attention to the plight of veterans recalls the socially engaged lyrics of E.Y. Harburg. The show defies you not to be moved by its valiant band of brothers.<U+201D>

Media: Theatermania
Review: <U+201C><U+2018>Bandstand<U+2019> explores the undeniable power that art has to change the world<U+2026>It also benefits from first-rate direction and choreography by Andy Blankenbuehler<U+2026>In terms of style, 'Bandstand' is refreshingly old-fashioned<U+2026>Osnes performs her two big numbers with a blistering intensity that is thrilling to behold. While not all of the songs fit comfortably in Cott's range, his work is as alive as it gets. It's an exhilarating, star-making turn.

Media: The New York Times
Review: <U+201C>An undercooked slice of apple pie, served with a dollop of anguish<U+2026>It<U+2019>s respectful of veterans, but not of itself, ultimately quitting on its own ambitions...Mr. Cott has a crushing charisma<U+2026>Ms. Osnes, a brunette with a silvery voice, puts real feeling behind Julia<U+2019>s loss<U+2026>But even fine actors can<U+2019>t make this story more persuasive. If <U+2018>Bandstand<U+2019> really worked, the finale would find you laughing and crying. Instead, you might just make like the dancers and shrug.

Media: The Hollywood Reporter
Review: <U+201C>While many of the numbers have the propulsive feel of big-band swing, none of them are particularly memorable, and the generic ballads frequently stop the show dead in its tracks<U+2026>Cott and Osnes are highly attractive and appealing performers, and they sing the hell out of their material<U+2026>But for all the strenuous effort and good intentions evident in <U+2018>Bandstand,<U+2019> it mainly demonstrates that if you<U+2019>re going to drop the name Dachau in a musical, it needs to be far better than this one.

Media: Lighting & Sound America
Review: All of these songs unfold in an onstage world jittery with energy, maddened by an irresistible swing beat, thanks to the tightly coiled staging of director/choreographer Blankenbuehler...Cott drives the action as Donny, offering galvanic vocals...Osnes finds a surprising (and welcome) amount of steel in Julia...Even in its more formulaic moments, the show continues to surprise. And its central point remains steadfast: These men risked everything for their country<U+2014>attention must be paid.

Media: New York Theater
Review: The cast is pitch-perfect...The catchy, beat-happy score pays homage to the big band era...Director and choreographer Andy Blankenbuehler seamlessly nods to 1940s popular dances in coming up with some lively, inventive moves, performed by some terrific dancers...All of this terrific entertainment and artistry is arranged around a plot that also recalls the 1940s, but ultimately not in a good way...The more the singing contest takes over the plot...the more the plot stumbles.

Media: Cultural Weekly
Review: Employing identically dressed chorus members, Blankenbuehler creates a shattered hall-of-mirrors vision of protagonist Donny<U+2019>s wartime memories...The plot follows a cliched track...Fortunately, Taylor and Oberacker delve deep into the traumas suffered by Donny and his crew and the score cleverly uses period music to create mood and explore the theme of the vets<U+2019> alienation...'Bandstand' does sing a familiar tune, but it has drawn up some new and arresting arrangements.

Media: Variety
Review: <U+201C>An earnest and often-entertaining musical that never quite achieves its noble ambitions. Despite the fluid staging and evocative choreography by Andy Blankenbuehler, an uneven book, undistinguished dialogue and only-serviceable tunes keep the show from meeting its deeper, darker and good-intentioned aspirations<U+2026>Oberacker pens the mood-setting, pleasant and easily forgettable pastiche songs and lyrics...The cast is made up of solid performers, most of who play their own instruments.

Media: Front Row Center
Review: <U+201C>What saves this from death by saccharine is the raw nerves of these veterans<U+2026>It is their story that trails after you when you leave...It is too bad that the authors were not able to take a pair of clippers to the book, and the stunning lack of a resolution doesn<U+2019>t help<U+2026>Cott and Osnes positively crackle and the ensemble work is spectacular in every way. But the basics of <U+2018>beginning, middle and end<U+2019> got left behind at the train depot. And all the big band music doesn<U+2019>t quite make up for that.

Media: Talkin' Broadway
Review: <U+201C>The conflict between what is and what should be is the powerful driving force behind this compelling evening<U+2026>Oberacker and Taylor have created a heartfelt show that works well on its own terms...The music is of the bold and infectious variety<U+2026>Too often, however, the songs aren't memorable<U+2026>Blankenbuehler fares better, his staging brisk and fluid<U+2026>Cott makes an arresting leading man<U+2026>Osnes looks and sounds smashing, though she could dig a bit deeper to find more of Julia's defining darkness.

Media: Broadway Blog
Review: <U+201C>A sincere, upbeat, but overly sudsy and clich<U+00E9>d musical<U+2026>They deserve a chutzpah Tony for creating a show in which the central characters are musicians who play, not the actual big band swing of 1945, when the show is set, but pastiches<U+2026>While 'Bandstand' never overcomes the impediment of its ersatz tunes, exciting director-choreographer Andy Blankenbuehler keeps our eyes and ears glued to his inventive staging, jitterbugging, and boogie-woogieing.

Media: The Huffington Post
Review: <U+201C>It<U+2019>s not going too far to suggest that the enthralling musical beats with the kind of heart that throbs throughout <U+2018>South Pacific<U+2019><U+2026>Arguably the best new musical of the season<U+2026>Oberacker and Taylor have written a work that brims with honesty<U+2026>Osnes gives the performance of her career so far. The voice is pure as mountain water<U+2026>The purity of her acting is what lifts her into a new performing stratum. Less well known, Cott finds every dimension of heartsick, furious, talented Donny.<U+201D>

Media: The Wall Street Journal
Review: The first act is straight off the rack, a concatenation of bone-tired clich<U+00E9>s strung together on an unexpectedly interesting premise. The second act isn<U+2019>t any more original, but it<U+2019>s more agreeable, and you<U+2019>ll likely feel that you<U+2019>ve been sufficiently entertained by the time the curtain falls...Corey Cott and Laura Osnes, who play the bandleader and his vocalist, are fresh-faced and appealing...The kind of unchallenging show to which you might feel inclined to take your visiting grandparents.

Media: AM New York
Review: <U+201C>An urgent testimonial to the healing and restorative power that the arts can have...Oberacker and Taylor created a swinging original score that not only captures the period style but also digs deep into the characters. Media: New York Magazine / Vulture
Review: <U+201C>I<U+2019>m not saying it<U+2019>s perfectly carried out, or even especially profound, but it remains almost compulsively faithful to its vision<U+2026>The darkness of the background does not mean that the show forswears entertainment<U+2026>Although it features some Golden Age attributes it is hardly at Golden Age level. Media: New York Daily News
Review: <U+201C>A well-meaning mishmash of a musical<U+2026>The authors<U+2019> idea is a good one<U+2026>But the show backburners this thread for a conventional story<U+2026>It<U+2019>s a bit all over the place<U+2026>Songs by Oberacker and Taylor are workmanlike and pleasant, but tend to be monochromatic<U+2026>Musically it<U+2019>s a blur. Media: Times Square Chronicles
Review: <U+201C>A show that never allows us to digest the horrors of what vets go through<U+2026>The cast is winning...Bender, Packard, Hopkins and Carroll are all terrific musicians and actors. Media: Deadline
Review: <U+201C>It is to Blankenbuehler<U+2019>s credit that the dazzling through-line of movement makes 'Bandstand' as much about dance as it is about music<U+2026>The movement in 'Bandstand' is seamless and eye-popping, managing an astonishing feat<U+2026>Oberacker and Taylor are clearly well versed in the musical idioms of the period and whose more-than-serviceable songs range from torchy ballads to roof-raising anthems...I have to wonder how this show was cast without a single non-Caucasian among the principals.

Media: Chicago Tribune
Review: <U+201C>Blankenbuehler's production just never stops for a moment, sometimes at the expense of the narrative flow...The dancing is, however, spectacular<U+2026><U+2018>Bandstand<U+2019> has a serviceable score, although there is so much music that it often tends to blur<U+2026>The book has moments of freshness and all kinds of potential, but it never strives enough for poetic heights or depth of characters<U+2026>All in all, this is a show with some frustrations as well as many pleasures for the ear and eye.

Media: Newsday
Review: <U+201C>The results, which intentionally jumble the dance focus in challenging ways, are visually and emotionally compelling. Media: The Wrap
Review: <U+201C>It has not been a spectacular season for dance on Broadway...There<U+2019>s almost no competition for Blankenbuehler<U+2019>s arresting choreography in the new musical <U+2018>Bandstand<U+2019><U+2026>All he needs now is a musical worthy of his talents. <U+2018>Bandstand<U+2019> is not that musical<U+2026>The book initially intrigues, because it<U+2019>s so damned dark for a Broadway musical<U+2026>Alcoholism, divorce, drugs, unemployment, and chronic war wounds are not a plot<U+2026>The second act is one long uneventful slog to the big city.

Media: Front Mezz Junkies

Media: Theater News Online
Review: Buoyed by a pair of charismatic, well-sung performances by the equally gorgeous Corey Cott and Laura Osnes, a tuneful score by Broadway newcomers Rob Taylor and Richard Obercraker, and some dynamite 1940s-inspired choreography by Tony winner Andy Blankenbuehler (who also directs), the show manages to prompt far more cheers than jeers <U+2013> despite some unfortunate missteps in the book and execution.

Media: Woman Around Town
Review: <U+201C>Osnes and Cott are fine singers and good actors<U+2026>One wishes them better luck next time. Muddy arrangements of music that lacks not only 1940s flavor but actual melody conflict with unoriginal lyrics which neither sync nor sing<U+2026>The book is the best thing about this piece. It has grit, wit and sincerity. While Blankenbuehler works well with his actors, overall action is often a mess<U+2026>In different hands, this might<U+2019>ve been a genial, vivacious show with a future in national touring.

Media: NY1
Review: Taylor and Oberacker did a fine job turning the story into a deeply engaging and moving work. With high intensity and just the right touch of humor, they deal sensitively with the emotional issues plaguing each of the characters, while director/choreographer Andy Blankenbuehler put it into exhilarating motion<U+2026>The music is appealingly catchy...With nary a false note in this production, 'Bandstand' creates sweet harmony from the dissonance of war.

Media: Theater Pizzazz
Review: <U+201C>A strong message along with a remarkably talented cast<U+2026>If you love the era of swing music, dance and saddle shoes, you<U+2019>re a good match for <U+2018>Bandstand<U+2019>...The deeper and darker side of this story never lets up, but it is eased by the crackerjack perpetual whirling, twirling and tapping group of ace dancers to high-energy new swing sounds<U+2026>Cott has emerged as a new leading man with his strong and powerful, yet edgy, charisma and fantastic vocals, aided by his lively dancing abilities.

Media: Out Magazine
Review: It<U+2019>s not cheesy. Blankenbuehler provides swirling movement and zippy choreography. The leads work hard, and deliver knockout numbers...But the net result feels like a noble flop. There<U+2019>s just too much music, and not all of it is top drawer. The story sometimes verges on a hackneyed Dick Powell movie. And for all the slickness and swing-era recreations, the mood borders on dullish...This one falls into the category of admirable misstep.

Media: DC Metro Theater Arts
Review: The most refreshing and imaginative of the bunch of recent arrivals...It<U+2019>s not all pastiche, not by a long shot. There is youthful invention everywhere...As Donny Novitsky, his current role, Cott delivers a true star turn<U+2013>as singer, actor, dancer, and pianist he dominates just as his character does...If 'Bandstand,' as the last musical entry of the season, is a hint, we have reason to hope we<U+2019>re in for a good time in the year ahead.

Media: CurtainUp
Review: Equally appealing to the ear and the eye. Since <U+2018>Bandstand<U+2019> is emotionally complex and largely unsentimental, it's likely to connect with the intellect and the heart of spectators of many, perhaps all, ages. But what audiences will remember most is Blankenbuehler's stunning dances performed by a talented corps of idiosyncratic Broadway professionals<U+2026>'Bandstand<U+2019> is superbly cast...A touching, funny, dry martini of a musical.

Media: Musical Theater Review
Review: It<U+2019>s an admirable but disconcertingly disjointed effort...The score is a mixed bag. It captures the driving tempos of the era<U+2019>s big band music, well realized in a plenitude of strong orchestrations. What<U+2019>s missing are the beguiling melodies and the deceptive simplicity of lyrics that transformed so many of the songs from that era into standards...Despite the uneven material, the cast scores its points...For Blankenbuehler, the show is a further validation of his skills.

Media: StageZine
Review: The joy of experiencing 'Bandstand' is seeing an original musical...The subject matter is familiar but still relevant today...The book seems contrived and you can see how things are going to fall in place. However, the score is transporting and the sound of the big band/swing era is exhilarating...With 'Bandstand' you may feel you<U+2019>ve seen this plot before, but who cares  Among the swing music, vitality, sound, Ms. Osnes and Mr. Cott, it is an evening of sheer delight.

Media: Theatre Reviews by John Clum
Review: The cast is enormously talented<U+2014>some sing, dance, act, and play instruments expertly. The music is catchy and tuneful, if forgettable...The band, onstage and in the pit is excellent...The dancing is fabulous...The fact that the script is so predictable is the show's principal problem. I kept trying to think of ways to make the book more interesting...For all its virtues, 'Bandstand' is saddled with a book that  resembles a 1940s B musical...The war flashbacks are pretty cheesy.

Media: Pop Dust
Review: While it flirts with cliche almost to the point of marriage, 'Bandstand' manages to stay on message and deliver a genuinely heartfelt and affecting story about the greatest generation's return home from World War II...Together this cast keep the energy high and the story blasting forward. Where 'Bandstand' succeeds to its fullest is in the music. Whether it's played by the orchestra or the cast, it's nothing short of perfect...'Bandstand' is so good that you don't think about its blindspots.

Media: NJ.com
Review: It is a stand-up-and-cheer great new musical that should not be missed...A war-story cliche or two might find space in the script...But much of the show's excellence comes from its treatment of the veterans as real people...Wonderful story and performances notwithstanding, much of its dazzle finds root in Andy Blankenbuehler's direction and choreography...It is at bottom an excellent new musical full of wonderful performances and bold, finely crafted music.

Media: Film Festival Traveler
Review: Sentimental but affecting...Osnes is the emotional center of a show that also generously allows each of the bandsmen to work out his demons by playing the music he loves. Media: Exeunt Magazine
Review: <U+201C>Successfully toes the line between nostalgia and refreshing realism<U+2026>The show<U+2019>s cast manages to capture these characters as both charismatic underdogs and the complex survivors whose joy always has a darker tinge<U+2026>Audiences looking forward to buoyant swing dance numbers won<U+2019>t be let down here<U+2026>The choreography works as an equal collaborator that elevates the book and score<U+2026>The choreography physically expresses the Big Band beats of Oberacker<U+2019>s score.

Media: LI Herald

Media: ZEALnyc
